newsitem.title: TURKEY: Cargill to build $300-mln fructose plant in Turkey.
newsitem.headline: Cargill to build $300-mln fructose plant in Turkey.

text.p: U.S. agriculture giant Cargill will invest a total of $300 million in Turkey to build a hi-tech plant to produce fructose, benefiting from an newly-planned incentive package for foreign capital, a Turkish government official said on Friday.
"The government is preparing a change in the legislation on foreign capital investments to give them incentives," said the official, who declined to be named.
"Cargill will initially invest $100 million in a fructose plant and the amount will be raised to $300 million in five years," he told Reuters.
He said such foreign capital investments would benefit from the new legislation, which would allow for cheaper inputs like electricity in production.

Officials said the change in the legislation was held up by the former coalition government between Islamists and conservatives, replaced last month by a secular three-party coalition that vowed to promote a free market economy.
According to the preliminary plans, the plant is envisaged to process 800 tonnes of corn a day to produce fructose, a natural sweetener derived from corn and used in soft drinks.
The plant will be built in Aslanbey region in Izmit province, to the east of Istanbul.
